p: Stepwise, backward multivariable linear regression analysis demonstrated that HIV infection and the use of anti-hypertensive therapy were both independently associated with higher glucose levels ( Table 2). Thus, HIV-positive subjects had glucose levels that were 4.40% higher than in HIV-negative subjects and subjects receiving anti-hypertensive therapy had glucose levels that were 6.90% higher than those not receiving such therapy ( Table 2). With regards to HbA1c levels, HIV infection was negatively associated with this variable, whilst BMI, glucose and use of statins were positively associated. Thus, HIV-positive subjects had HbA1c levels that were 2.80% lower than those without HIV, a 1 unit increase in BMI was associated with a 0.30% increase in HbA1c, a 1 mmol/L increase in glucose levels was associated with a 1.20% increase in HbA1c, whilst subjects on statins had a 3.00% higher HbA1c level than those not taking statin therapy ( Table 2).
